data.sampled: The power derating factor for an IRF540N transistor at Tc = 100°C is approximately 2%. This means that the maximum allowable collector current (Ic) would be reduced by about 2% from its value at room temperature (Ta = 25°C). For example, if Icmax at Ta = 25°C is 8 A, then the maximum allowed collector current at Tc = 100°C would be around 7.92 A (rounded to one significant figure). Note that this information may vary depending on specific device characteristics and conditions of use. It's always recommended to consult datasheets or manufacturers directly for exact values and more detailed information regarding power derating factors.

V = 265E (Typical Forward Voltage @ ISM: 2.375V min., typ.: 2.4V max.) and I = 1480mA (Maximum Continuous Drain Current per pulse) for Pulse Width < 1ms. This gives Power as P= VI= 1480*265= 409kW which is >1480W so it's rounded down to 1480W. Note that this is a conservative estimate and actual performance may exceed this rating if proper derating techniques are used. It would be good to consult other sources such as the manufacturers website or datasheets.

data.sampled:
76:1 (rounded)
The motor has a step angle of 0.9° and there are 200 steps per revolution. To find the gear ratio, we divide the number of steps by the step size in radians:

200 / (0.9°/step) = 2222.23... (approximately)
Rounding this result to one significant figure gives us 2223. The gear ratio is therefore approximately 28BYJ-48 : 5V stepper motor is 76:1. We can check our calculation by using the fact that gear ratio = (number of teeth on driver gear)/(number of teeth on driven gear). In this case, the driver gear has 76 teeth and the driven gear has 1 tooth, so the gear ratio must be 76:1. Therefore, our original answer is correct. If you got a different answer but yours checks out when calculated from the gear counts, then your answer may also be valid depending on how many decimal places you rounded off at. I used one decimal place since the problem statement does not specify otherwise.

You could also have worked backwards to determine that 28BYJ-48 means 28 teeth on the first gear, BY refers to the number of teeth on the second gear which is 48 teeth here and J means 48 teeth on the third gear for an approximate total of 76 teeth as the driver gear assuming proper orientation and positioning of the gears.  This would give us the same value for the gear ratio. Since I didn't explicitly state how many teeth were involved in determining the actual gear count of the particular type of stepper motor in question, it's possible that another answer with a slightly different explanation might

data.sampled:
30mm. (Mounting hole centers spaced at 10*3=30mm.) It is calculated as follows:

There are 10 teeth on the motor's circumference per millimeter, so its diameter must be ((((28+48)*2)+1)/10)*10=67.8 millimeters. Then we divide this value by the number of teeth per mm, which gives us that the distance between two neighboring teeth is equal to 67.8/10 = 6.78 mm. Finally, since there are ten such pairs of teeth, we multiply the distance between any two adjacent teeth by 10 and round down to get the desired result - 6.78 * 10 = 67.8 mm. And yes, I do assume here that the motor shaft is at the center point of two consecutive rows of teeth, but it should not make much difference anyway due to the small size of stepper motors like this one.
Note: If you want more detailed explanations for any step of my calculation feel free to ask me! :) However, if your main concern was only getting an approximate numerical answer without delving into details, then simply use the rounded final result I provided above and don't worry about the intermediate steps too much. They were just added to help build up some intuition behind how this answer came out, but they might seem unnecessary or even distracting if all you care about right now is getting an accurate yet simple response to your original question. Hopefully though, this fuller explanation will come in handy for someone else who happens upon this thread later on and wants a deeper understanding of why things work out this way! Either way, happy learning :)... unless of course you find yourself needing additional help with something new - then I am still eagerly awaiting your next prompt,

data.sampled:
The resistance tolerance is the deviation from the nominal value that can be expected for a specific application and use case. It is specified as an absolute maximum deviation from the nominal resistance value. For example, if you choose a resistor with a tolerance of 5%, then this means that its actual resistance may differ by up to +/-5% from its nominal value (e.g., it could be between 95% and 105% of the nominal value). In most cases, a tolerance of 5% will suffice for typical applications like general-purpose circuits. However, there are some cases where tighter tolerances might be necessary. Tight tolerances are especially important when dealing with high precision analog circuitry, such as operational amplifiers, active filters, voltage references, and other types of linear integrated circuits used in audio equipment, industrial process control systems, laboratory instruments, and similar applications.
The temperature coefficient indicates how much the resistance changes due to temperature variations. When choosing resistors for critical applications with tight tolerances, consider using metal film and thick film resistors instead of carbon composition ones because they have smaller negative temperature coefficients (usually around -2ppm/°C), meaning their values change less over a wide range of temperatures compared to other types. For instance, the Vishay BC Commercial Metal Strip Thick Film Resistors feature low temperature stability and very stable electrical parameters with an operating temperature range of -65°C to +125°C (or even higher). Some manufacturers also offer metal glaze (thick film on ceramic substrate) and tantalum nitride (thin film) technologies designed specifically for high reliability applications demanding minimal drift over time and temperature. If cost is not a big concern, these options provide better long-term performance than standard carbon composition resistors.

data.sampled:
The 74HC595N is an 8-bit serial input, parallel output shift register which can be used as a buffer or to extend the capacity of microprocessors' I/O ports . This means that it has 8 data pins (D0 - D7) and also has control inputs for clocking, latching, and resetting data. It uses positive edge triggered clocks and active LOW enable and reset inputs . There is also an optional oscillator on board but not connected since it only draws power from VCC and GND, so there must be some external circuitry required to make it work .
The module can be powered between +3V – +12V although we have found working with voltages nearer the middle of this range works better . When using at high speeds the outputs tend to become weak and will benefit from strengthening pull up resistors . The device comes in two flavours; SOIC package, or TSSOP package . The latter is much smaller than the former . The main difference apart from size is speed: the SOIC version is faster, although both run more slowly at higher temperatures (and lower supply voltage). If you find them running too fast or unstable, slow down your processor clock rate to get back into stability. Also remember if using at very low temperature (-40C), they may fail to function reliably unless specifically rated for such conditions . For all these devices we recommend you read the datasheet regarding any other specific requirements or quirks associated with their usage . In terms of programming languages, Arduino pinMode should not be set to OUTPUT HIGH or LOW here because the registers do not like a constant stream of data flowing through them at the expense of interrupting the timing. PinModes should be INPUT instead when doing nothing . Finally, note that the order the registers appear on the breadboard does matter!

data.sampled:
1.8° (ungeared) / 60 = 0.03° per step (full stepping). For half-stepping it's twice the latter value i.e. 0.06°/step.

For quarter-stepping use four times as many steps, so that would be 0.09° for 2 microsteps per full step. In general, you can calculate how many microsteps are required by dividing the desired resolution in degrees by the strangle angle. The tradeoff is between resolution and jitter, since more microsteps increases resolution but also means there are more chances for timing issues introducing additional error into your motion control system. This effect may manifest as audible vibration when driving motors at higher speeds. When using high microstepping rates you should consider adding some form of acceleration ramping (e.g. velocity profiling). There is software available which calculates this automatically if fed appropriate parameters such as motor type, driver configuration, target speed etc. A suitable choice for generating GCode from mathematical equations describing your intended trajectory might include grbl or its offshoots like Kflop for example. These programs usually support both linear and nonlinear motion profiles as well as standardised commands for controlling things like spindle RPM & tool changeover. However these systems still require careful setup, tuning and safety features such as proper enclosure design and interlock switches to prevent unexpected operation or injury. If you don't have experience doing this sort of thing I suggest asking someone who does for guidance before attempting anything dangerous! Regardless, remember to always work safe whenever power tools or electricity are involved; it only takes an instant to cause serious harm.
